datafield.subfield: Hypernuclear matter in strong magnetic field
Hypernuclear matter in strong magnetic field
Dense matter is strong magnetic fields

6 pages, 2 figures: Older version has been moved to 1005.4995 as version 3. This version has been prepared as Proceedings of International Conference on "The Modern Physics of Compact Stars and Relativistic Gravity", 18-21 September 2013, Yerevan, Armenia with related material

Compact stars having strong magnetic fields (magnetars) have been observationally determined to have surface magnetic fields of order of 10^14-10^15 G, the implied internal field strength being several orders larger. We study the equation of state and composition of hypernuclear matter and quark matter - two forms of dense matter in strong magnetic fields. We find that the magnetic field has substantial influence on the properties of hypernuclear matter and quark matter for magnetic field B \ge 10^17 G and B \ge 10^18 G respectively. In particular the matter properties become anisotropic. Moreover, above a critical field B_cr, both hypernuclear and quark matter show instability, although the values of B_cr are different for two kinds of matter.

00003 Dependence of $\gamma_c$ - the critical value of $\gamma$ parameter - on the logarithm of $\beta$ parameter. The solid line corresponds to the field $B_c = 3\times 10^{18}$~G, the dashed line - to $B_c = 10^{18}$~G
00004 Dependence of matter pressure on normalized baryon number density without the $B^2/8\pi$ term, which demonstrates the effect of Landau quantization.

00002 {\it Upper panels:} Dependence of $P_\parallel$ and $B$ on the normalized baryon number density for different magnetic field profiles and $B_c=10^{18}$ G. The dots show the reference case $B_c=0$. The solid and dashed lines correspond to $\beta=0.1$ and $0.001$, respectively. For each $\beta$ we choose a pair of $\gamma$'s; in the first case we have $\gamma =1$ and $\gamma = 4$, whereas in the second case $\gamma = 1$ and $\gamma = 6$. The first $\gamma$ value for each $\beta$ corresponds to a less steeply rising curve. {\it Lower panels:} Same as in the upper pannel but for $B_c=3\times10^{18}$~G and $\gamma = 1$ and $\gamma = 1.4$ for $\beta=0.1$ and $\gamma = 1$ and $\gamma = 3.5$ for $\beta=10^{-3}$. The specific values of $\gamma$'s were chosen to demonstrate the onset of instability.
00005 Abundances of different species as functions of normalized baryon number density without (left panel) and with (right panel) magnetic field.

00001 {\it Left panel:} Variation of total pressure as a function of normalized baryon number density for fixed magnetic fields $B_c = 0$ and $B_c = 10^{18}$~G and several field profiles, $\beta = 10^{-3}$, $\gamma = 6$ (dashed lines), $\beta = 10^{-1}$, $\gamma = 4$ (dashed-double-dotted lines), and $\beta \to \infty$, \ie $B_c =$ constant (dashed-dotted lines). For each pair of curves the upper branch is for $P_\perp$ and the lower branch for $P_\parallel$. {\it Right panel:} Same as in the left panel, but for fixed $\beta = 10^{-1}$, $\gamma = 1$ and for two values of $B$-field, $B_c = 10^{18}$ G (dashed lines) and $B_c = 3\times 10^{18}$~G (dashed-dotted lines). The solid line corresponds to the case $B_c = 0$.

00000 {\it Left panel:} Variation of total pressure as a function of normalized baryon number density for fixed magnetic fields $B_c = 0$ and $B_c = 10^{18}$~G and several field profiles, $\beta = 10^{-3}$, $\gamma = 6$ (dashed lines), $\beta = 10^{-1}$, $\gamma = 4$ (dashed-double-dotted lines), and $\beta \to \infty$, \ie $B_c =$ constant (dashed-dotted lines). For each pair of curves the upper branch is for $P_\perp$ and the lower branch for $P_\parallel$. {\it Right panel:} Same as in the left panel, but for fixed $\beta = 10^{-1}$, $\gamma = 1$ and for two values of $B$-field, $B_c = 10^{18}$ G (dashed lines) and $B_c = 3\times 10^{18}$~G (dashed-dotted lines). The solid line corresponds to the case $B_c = 0$.
